standard_metadata.standard_description: Add and subtract fractions with unlike denominators (including mixed numbers) by replacing given fractions with equivalent fractions in such a way as to produce an equivalent sum or difference of fractions with like denominators.

hints.content: Before we can subtract our fractions, they need to have the same denominator.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: Two groups with three rectangles each. The rectangles in the top group are split into 2 equal parts each. Each part is labeled one-half. All six parts are shaded. A curved bracket across the shaded parts is labeled six-halves. The rectangles in the bottom group are split into three equal parts each. Each part is labeled one-third. One part is shaded. The end of the part in the third rectangle in the bottom group aligns with the end of the shaded part of the top group of rectangles. A curved bracket across the shaded part is labeled one-third. A curved bracket below the next eight unshaded parts is labeled six-halves minus one-third.

hints.content: Let's look at the multiples of each denominator and see which multiples they have in common.  Denominator | Multiples :-: | :-: $\greenD{2}$ | $2, {4}, \underline{6}$ $\purpleD{3}$ | $3, \underline{6}, 9$  The least common denominator is ${6}$.

Let's use multiplication to make each fraction have a denominator of $6$.  $\greenD{\dfrac{6}{2}}=\dfrac{\greenD{6} \times 3}{\greenD{2} \times 3} = {\dfrac\greenD{18}\greenD{6}}$  $\purpleD{\dfrac{1}{3}}=\dfrac{\purpleD{1} \times 2}{\purpleD{3} \times 2} = {\dfrac\purpleD{2}\purpleD{6}}$

images.alt: Two groups with three rectangles each. The rectangles in the top group are split into 2 equal parts each. Each part is further split into 3 smaller equal groups. All eighteen of the smaller groups are shaded. A curved bracket across the shaded parts is labeled eighteen-sixths. The rectangles in the bottom group are split into 3 equal parts each. Each part is further split into 2 equal parts. Two parts are shaded in purple. Sixteen parts are shaded in pink. The shaded parts in the bottom group are equal in size to the shaded part in the top group. A curved bracket across the purple shaded parts is labeled two-sixths. A curved bracket below the pink shaded parts is labeled eighteen-sixths minus two-sixths.

hints.content: $\greenD{\dfrac{6}{2}} - \purpleD{\dfrac{1}{3}} = \dfrac{16}{6}$  We can also write $\dfrac{16}{6}$ as $\dfrac83$ or $2\dfrac23$.
Before we can subtract our fractions, they need to have the same denominator.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: Two groups with three rectangles each. The rectangles in the top group are split into 3 equal parts each. Each part is labeled one-third. Eight parts are shaded. A curved bracket across the shaded parts is labeled eight-thirds. The rectangles in the bottom group are split into four equal parts each. Each part is labeled one-fourth. Six parts are shaded. A portion of the third part in the third rectangle in the bottom group aligns with the end of the shaded part of the top group of rectangles. A curved bracket across the shaded part is labeled six-fourths. A curved bracket below the next four unshaded parts and a portion of the fifth part is labeled eight-thirds minus six-fourths.

hints.content: Let's look at the multiples of each denominator and see which multiples they have in common.  Denominator | Multiples :-: | :-: $\greenD{3}$ | $3, {6}, 9, \underline{12}$ $\purpleD{4}$ | $4, 8, \underline{12}, 16$  The least common denominator is ${12}$.

Let's use multiplication to make each fraction have a denominator of $12$.  $\greenD{\dfrac{8}{3}}=\dfrac{\greenD{8} \times 4}{\greenD{3} \times 4} = {\dfrac\greenD{32}\greenD{12}}$  $\purpleD{\dfrac{6}{4}}=\dfrac{\purpleD{6} \times 3}{\purpleD{4} \times 3} = {\dfrac\purpleD{18}\purpleD{12}}$

images.alt: Two groups with three rectangles each. The rectangles in the top group are split into 3 equal parts each. Each part is further split into 4 smaller equal groups. Thirty-two of the smaller groups are shaded. A curved bracket across the shaded parts is labeled thirty-two twelfths. The rectangles in the bottom group are split into 4 equal parts each. Each part is further split into 3 equal parts. Eighteen parts are shaded in purple. Fourteen parts are shaded in pink. The shaded parts in the bottom group are equal in size to the shaded part in the top group. A curved bracket across the purple shaded parts is labeled eighteen-twelfths. A curved bracket below the pink shaded parts is labeled thirty-two twelfths minus eighteen-twelfths.

hints.content: $\greenD{\dfrac{8}{3}} - \purpleD{\dfrac{6}{4}} = \dfrac{14}{12}$  We can also write $\dfrac{14}{12}$ as $\dfrac76$ or $1\dfrac16$.
Before we can subtract our fractions, they need to have the same denominator.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: Two groups with four rectangles each. The rectangles in the top group are split into 2 equal parts each. Each part is labeled one-half. Seven parts are shaded. A curved bracket across the shaded parts is labeled seven-halves. The rectangles in the bottom group are split into six equal parts each. Seven parts are shaded. The end of the third part in the fourth rectangle in the bottom group aligns with the end of the shaded part of the top group of rectangles. A curved bracket across the shaded part is labeled seven-sixths. A curved bracket below the next fourteen unshaded parts is labeled seven-halves minus seven-sixths.

hints.content: Let's look at the multiples of each denominator and see which multiples they have in common.  Denominator | Multiples :-: | :-: $\greenD{2}$ | $2, {4}, \underline{6}$ $\purpleD{6}$ | $\underline{6}, 12, 18$  The least common denominator is ${6}$.
Let's use multiplication to make each fraction have a denominator of $6$.  $\greenD{\dfrac{7}{2}}=\dfrac{\greenD{7} \times 3}{\greenD{2} \times 3} = {\dfrac\greenD{21}\greenD{6}}$

images.alt: Two groups with four rectangles each. The rectangles in the top group are split into 2 equal parts each. Each part is further split into 3 smaller equal groups. Twenty-one of the smaller groups are shaded. A curved bracket across the shaded parts is labeled twenty-one sixths. The rectangles in the bottom group are split into 6 equal parts each. Seven parts are shaded in purple. Fourteen parts are shaded in pink. The shaded parts in the bottom group are equal in size to the shaded part in the top group. A curved bracket across the purple shaded parts is labeled seven-sixths. A curved bracket below the pink shaded parts is labeled twenty-one sixths minus seven-sixths.

hints.content: $\greenD{\dfrac{7}{2}} - \purpleD{\dfrac{7}{6}} = \dfrac{14}{6}$  We can also write $\dfrac{14}{6}$ as $\dfrac73$ or $2\dfrac13$.
Before we can subtract our fractions, they need to have the same denominator.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: Two groups with three rectangles each. The rectangles in the top group are split into 2 equal parts each. Each part is labeled one-half. Five parts are shaded. A curved bracket across the shaded parts is labeled five-halves. The rectangles in the bottom group are split into eight equal parts each. Each part is labeled one-eighth. Six parts are shaded. The end of the fourth part in the third rectangle in the bottom group aligns with the end of the shaded part of the top group of rectangles. A curved bracket across the shaded part is labeled six-eighths. A curved bracket below the next fourteen unshaded parts is labeled five-halves minus six-eighths.

hints.content: Let's look at the multiples of each denominator and see which multiples they have in common.  Denominator | Multiples :-: | :-: $\greenD{2}$ | $2, {4}, 6, \underline{8}$ $\purpleD{8}$ | $\underline{8}, 16, 24$  The least common denominator is ${8}$.
Let's use multiplication to make each fraction have a denominator of $8$.  $\greenD{\dfrac{5}{2}}=\dfrac{\greenD{5} \times 4}{\greenD{2} \times 4} = {\dfrac\greenD{20}\greenD{8}}$

images.alt: Two groups with three rectangles each. The rectangles in the top group are split into 2 equal parts each. Each part is further split into 4 smaller equal groups. Twenty of the smaller groups are shaded. A curved bracket across the shaded parts is labeled twenty-eighths. The rectangles in the bottom group are split into 8 equal parts each. Six parts are shaded in purple. Fourteen parts are shaded in pink. The shaded parts in the bottom group are equal in size to the shaded part in the top group. A curved bracket across the purple shaded parts is labeled six-eighths. A curved bracket below the pink shaded parts is labeled twenty-eighths minus six-eighths.

hints.content: $\greenD{\dfrac{5}{2}} - \purpleD{\dfrac{6}{8}} = \dfrac{14}{8}$  We can also write $\dfrac{14}{8}$ as $\dfrac74$ or $1\dfrac34$.
Before we can subtract our fractions, they need to have the same denominator.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: Two groups with four rectangles each. The rectangles in the top group are split into 2 equal parts each. All eight parts are shaded. A curved bracket across the shaded parts is labeled eight-halves. The rectangles in the bottom group are split into twelve equal parts each. Seven parts are shaded. The end of the twelfth part in the fourth rectangle in the bottom group aligns with the end of the shaded part of the top group of rectangles. A curved bracket across the shaded part is labeled seven-twelfths. A curved bracket below the next forty-one unshaded parts is labeled eight-halves minus seven-twelfths.

hints.content: Let's look at the multiples of each denominator and see which multiples they have in common.  Denominator | Multiples :-: | :-: $\greenD{2}$ | $2, {4}, 6, 8, 10, \underline{12}$ $\purpleD{12}$ | $\underline{12}, 24, 36$  The least common denominator is ${12}$.
Let's use multiplication to make each fraction have a denominator of $12$.  $\greenD{\dfrac{8}{2}}=\dfrac{\greenD{8} \times 6}{\greenD{2} \times 6} = {\dfrac\greenD{48}\greenD{12}}$

images.alt: Two groups with four rectangles each. The rectangles in the top group are split into 2 equal parts each. Each part is further split into 6 smaller equal groups. All forty-eight of the smaller groups are shaded. A curved bracket across the shaded parts is labeled forty-eighth twelfths. The rectangles in the bottom group are split into 12 equal parts each. Seven parts are shaded in purple. Forty-one parts are shaded in pink. The shaded parts in the bottom group are equal in size to the shaded part in the top group. A curved bracket across the purple shaded parts is labeled seven-twelfths. A curved bracket below the pink shaded parts is labeled forty-eight twelfths minus seven-twelfths.

hints.content: Before we can subtract our fractions, they need to have the same denominator.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: Two groups with three rectangles each. The rectangles in the top group are split into 3 equal parts each. Each part is labeled one-third. Eight parts are shaded. A curved bracket across the shaded parts is labeled eight-thirds. The rectangles in the bottom group are split into five equal parts each. Each part is labeled one-fifth. One part is shaded. A portion of the fourth part in the third rectangle in the bottom group aligns with the end of the shaded part of the top group of rectangles. A curved bracket across the shaded part is labeled one-fifth. A curved bracket below the next twelve unshaded parts and a portion of thirteenth part is labeled eight-thirds minus one-fifth.

hints.content: Let's look at the multiples of each denominator and see which multiples they have in common.  Denominator | Multiples :-: | :-: $\greenD{3}$ | $3, 6, 9, 12, \underline{15}, 18$ $\purpleD{5}$ | $5, 10, \underline{15}, 20, 25$  The least common denominator is ${15}$.

Let's use multiplication to make each fraction have a denominator of $15$.  $\greenD{\dfrac{8}{3}}=\dfrac{\greenD{8} \times 5}{\greenD{3} \times 5} = {\dfrac\greenD{40}\greenD{15}}$  $\purpleD{\dfrac{1}{5}}=\dfrac{\purpleD{1} \times 3}{\purpleD{5} \times 3} = {\dfrac\purpleD{3}\purpleD{15}}$

images.alt: Two groups with three rectangles each. The rectangles in the top group are split into 3 equal parts each. Each part is further split into 5 smaller equal groups. Forty of the smaller groups are shaded. A curved bracket across the shaded parts is labeled forty-fifteenths. The rectangles in the bottom group are split into 5 equal parts each. Each part is further split into 3 equal parts. Three parts are shaded in purple. Thirty-seven parts are shaded in pink. The shaded parts in the bottom group are equal in size to the shaded part in the top group. A curved bracket across the purple shaded parts is labeled three-fifteenths. A curved bracket below the pink shaded parts is labeled forty-fifteenths minus three-fifteenths.

hints.content: Before we can subtract our fractions, they need to have the same denominator.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: Two groups with three rectangles each. The rectangles in the top group are split into 3 equal parts each. Each part is labeled one-third. Eight parts are shaded. A curved bracket across the shaded parts is labeled eight-thirds. The rectangles in the bottom group are split into six equal parts each. Each part is labeled one-sixth. Two parts are shaded. The end of the fourth part in the third rectangle in the bottom group aligns with the end of the shaded part of the top group of rectangles. A curved bracket across the shaded part is labeled two-sixths. A curved bracket below the next fourteen unshaded parts is labeled eight-thirds minus two-sixths.

hints.content: Let's look at the multiples of each denominator and see which multiples they have in common.  Denominator | Multiples :-: | :-: $\greenD{3}$ | $3,  \underline{6}, 9$ $\purpleD{6}$ | $\underline{6}, 12, 18$  The least common denominator is ${6}$.
Let's use multiplication to make each fraction have a denominator of $6$.  $\greenD{\dfrac{8}{3}}=\dfrac{\greenD{8} \times 2}{\greenD{3} \times 2} = {\dfrac\greenD{16}\greenD{6}}$

images.alt: Two groups with three rectangles each. The rectangles in the top group are split into 3 equal parts each. Each part is further split into 2 smaller equal groups. Sixteen of the smaller groups are shaded. A curved bracket across the shaded parts is labeled sixteen-sixths. The rectangles in the bottom group are split into 6 equal parts each. Two parts are shaded in purple. Fourteen parts are shaded in pink. The shaded parts in the bottom group are equal in size to the shaded part in the top group. A curved bracket across the purple shaded parts is labeled two-sixths. A curved bracket below the pink shaded parts is labeled sixteen-sixths minus two-sixths.

hints.content: $\greenD{\dfrac{8}{3}} - \purpleD{\dfrac{2}{6}} = \dfrac{14}{6}$  We can also write $\dfrac{14}{6}$ as $\dfrac{7}{3}$ or $2\dfrac13$.
Before we can subtract our fractions, they need to have the same denominator.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: Two groups with three rectangles each. The rectangles in the top group are split into 3 equal parts each. Each part is labeled one-third. Eight parts are shaded. A curved bracket across the shaded parts is labeled eight-thirds. The rectangles in the bottom group are split into eight equal parts each. Each part is labeled one-eighth. Two parts are shaded. A portion of the sixth part in the third rectangle in the bottom group aligns with the end of the shaded part of the top group of rectangles. A curved bracket across the shaded part is labeled two-eighths. A curved bracket below the next nineteen unshaded parts and a portion of twentieth part is labeled eight-thirds minus two-eighths.

hints.content: Let's look at the multiples of each denominator and see which multiples they have in common.  Denominator | Multiples :-: | :-: $\greenD{3}$ | $3,  {6}, 9, 12, 15, 18, 21, \underline{24}$ $\purpleD{8}$ | $8, 16, \underline{24}, 32$  The least common denominator is ${24}$.

Let's use multiplication to make each fraction have a denominator of $24$.  $\greenD{\dfrac{8}{3}}=\dfrac{\greenD{8} \times 8}{\greenD{3} \times 8} = {\dfrac\greenD{64}\greenD{24}}$  $\purpleD{\dfrac{2}{8}}=\dfrac{\purpleD{2} \times 3}{\purpleD{8} \times 3} = {\dfrac\purpleD{6}\purpleD{24}}$

images.alt: Two groups with three rectangles each. The rectangles in the top group are split into 3 equal parts each. Each part is further split into 8 smaller equal groups. Sixty-four of the smaller groups are shaded. A curved bracket across the shaded parts is labeled sixty-four twenty-fourths. The rectangles in the bottom group are split into 8 equal parts each. Each part is further split into 3 equal parts. Six parts are shaded in purple. Fifty-eight parts are shaded in pink. The shaded parts in the bottom group are equal in size to the shaded part in the top group. A curved bracket across the purple shaded parts is labeled six twenty-fourths A curved bracket below the pink shaded parts is labeled sixty-four twenty-fourths minus six twenty-fourths.

hints.content: $\greenD{\dfrac{8}{3}} - \purpleD{\dfrac{2}{8}} = \dfrac{58}{24}$  We can also write $\dfrac{58}{24}$ as $\dfrac{29}{12}$ or $2\dfrac{5}{12}$.
Before we can subtract our fractions, they need to have the same denominator.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: Two groups with three rectangles each. The rectangles in the top group are split into 3 equal parts each. Each part is labeled one-third. All nine parts are shaded. A curved bracket across the shaded parts is labeled nine-thirds. The rectangles in the bottom group are split into ten equal parts each. Each part is labeled one-tenth. Six parts are shaded. The end of the tenth part in the third rectangle in the bottom group aligns with the end of the shaded part of the top group of rectangles. A curved bracket across the shaded part is labeled six-tenths. A curved bracket below the next twenty-four unshaded parts is labeled nine-thirds minus six-tenths.

hints.content: Let's look at the multiples of each denominator and see which multiples they have in common.  Denominator | Multiples :-: | :-: $\greenD{3}$ | $3,  {6}, 9, 12, 15, 18, 21, 24, 27, \underline{30}$ $\purpleD{10}$ | $10,20, \underline{30}, 40$  The least common denominator is ${30}$.

Let's use multiplication to make each fraction have a denominator of $30$.  $\greenD{\dfrac{9}{3}}=\dfrac{\greenD{9} \times {10}}{\greenD{3} \times {10}} = {\dfrac\greenD{90}\greenD{30}}$  $\purpleD{\dfrac{6}{10}}=\dfrac{\purpleD{6} \times 3}{\purpleD{10} \times 3} = {\dfrac\purpleD{18}\purpleD{30}}$

images.alt: Two groups with three rectangles each. The rectangles in the top group are split into 3 equal parts each. Each part is further split into 10 smaller equal groups. All ninety of the smaller groups are shaded. A curved bracket across the shaded parts is labeled ninety-thirtieths. The rectangles in the bottom group are split into 10 equal parts each. Each part is further split into 3 equal parts. Eighteen parts are shaded in purple. Seventy-two parts are shaded in pink. The shaded parts in the bottom group are equal in size to the shaded part in the top group. A curved bracket across the purple shaded parts is labeled eighteen-thirtieths. A curved bracket below the pink shaded parts is labeled ninety-thirtieths minus eighteen-thirtieths.

hints.content: $\greenD{\dfrac{9}{3}} - \purpleD{\dfrac{6}{10}} = \dfrac{72}{30}$  We can also write $\dfrac{72}{30}$ as $\dfrac{12}{5}$ or $2\dfrac{2}{5}$.
Before we can subtract our fractions, they need to have the same denominator.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: Two groups with three rectangles each. The rectangles in the top group are split into 3 equal parts each. All nine parts are shaded. A curved bracket across the shaded parts is labeled nine-thirds. The rectangles in the bottom group are split into twelve equal parts each. Eight parts are shaded. The end of the twelfth part in the third rectangle in the bottom group aligns with the end of the shaded part of the top group of rectangles. A curved bracket across the shaded part is labeled eight-twelfth. A curved bracket below the next twenty-eight unshaded parts is labeled nine-thirds minus eight-twelfths.

hints.content: Let's look at the multiples of each denominator and see which multiples they have in common.  Denominator | Multiples :-: | :-: $\greenD{3}$ | $3,  {6}, 9, \underline{12}, 15$ $\purpleD{12}$ | $\underline{12},24, 36$  The least common denominator is ${12}$.
Let's use multiplication to make each fraction have a denominator of $12$.  $\greenD{\dfrac{9}{3}}=\dfrac{\greenD{9} \times {4}}{\greenD{3} \times {4}} = {\dfrac\greenD{36}\greenD{12}}$

images.alt: Two groups with three rectangles each. The rectangles in the top group are split into 3 equal parts each. Each part is further split into 4 smaller equal groups. Eight parts are shaded in purple. Twenty-eight parts are shaded in pink. The shaded parts in the bottom group are equal in size to the shaded part in the top group. A curved bracket across the purple shaded parts is labeled eight-twelfths. A curved bracket below the pink shaded parts is labeled thirty-six twelfths minus eight-twelfths.

hints.content: $\greenD{\dfrac{9}{3}} - \purpleD{\dfrac{8}{12}} = \dfrac{28}{12}$  We can also write $\dfrac{28}{12}$ as $\dfrac{7}{3}$ or $2\dfrac{1}{3}$.
Before we can subtract our fractions, they need to have the same denominator.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: Two groups with two rectangles each. The rectangles in the top group are split into 6 equal parts each. Eight parts are shaded. A curved bracket across the shaded parts is labeled eight-sixths. The rectangles in the bottom group are split into four equal parts each. Five parts are shaded. There is a line dividing the second part of the second rectangle into two unequal parts. This line aligns with the end of the shaded part of the top group of rectangles. A curved bracket across the shaded parts is labeled five-fourths. A curved bracket below the unequal segment of the second rectangle is labeled eight-sixths minus five-fourths.

hints.content: Let's look at the multiples of each denominator and see which multiples they have in common.  Denominator | Multiples :-: | :-: $\greenD{6}$ | $6,  \underline{12}, 18$ $\purpleD{4}$ | $4, 8, \underline{12}, 16$  The least common denominator is ${12}$.

Let's use multiplication to make each fraction have a denominator of $12$.  $\greenD{\dfrac{8}{6}}=\dfrac{\greenD{8} \times {2}}{\greenD{6} \times {2}} = {\dfrac\greenD{16}\greenD{12}}$  $\purpleD{\dfrac{5}{4}}=\dfrac{\purpleD{5} \times 3}{\purpleD{4} \times 3} = {\dfrac\purpleD{15}\purpleD{12}}$

hints.content: Let's look at the multiples of each denominator and see which multiples they have in common.  Denominator | Multiples :-: | :-: $\greenD{4}$ | $4,  {8}, 12, 16, \underline{20}$ $\purpleD{10}$ | $10, \underline{20}, 30$  The least common denominator is ${20}$.

Let's use multiplication to make each fraction have a denominator of $20$.  $\greenD{\dfrac{9}{4}}=\dfrac{\greenD{9} \times {5}}{\greenD{4} \times {5}} = {\dfrac\greenD{45}\greenD{20}}$  $\purpleD{\dfrac{5}{10}}=\dfrac{\purpleD{5} \times 2}{\purpleD{10} \times 2} = {\dfrac\purpleD{10}\purpleD{20}}$

A curved bracket below the pink shaded parts is labeled forty-five twentieths minus ten-twentieths.

hints.content: $\greenD{\dfrac{9}{4}} - \purpleD{\dfrac{5}{10}} = \dfrac{35}{20}$  We can also write $\dfrac{35}{20}$ as $\dfrac{7}{4}$ or $1\dfrac{3}{4}$.

hints.content: Let's look at the multiples of each denominator and see which multiples they have in common.  Denominator | Multiples :-: | :-: $\greenD{4}$ | $4,  {8}, \underline{12}, 16$ $\purpleD{12}$ | $ \underline{12}, 24, 36$  The least common denominator is ${12}$.
Let's use multiplication to make each fraction have a denominator of $12$.  $\greenD{\dfrac{3}{4}}=\dfrac{\greenD{3} \times {3}}{\greenD{4} \times {3}} = {\dfrac\greenD{9}\greenD{12}}$

A curved bracket across the shaded part is labeled one-sixth. A curved bracket below the next five unshaded parts of the first bottom rectangle and the three and one-half unshaded parts of the second bottom rectangle is labeled eight-fifths minus one-sixth.

hints.content: Let's look at the multiples of each denominator and see which multiples they have in common.  Denominator | Multiples :-: | :-: $\greenD{5}$ | $5,  {10}, 15, 20, 25, \underline{30}$ $\purpleD{6}$ | $6, 12, 18, 24,  \underline{30}$  The least common denominator is ${30}$.

Let's use multiplication to make each fraction have a denominator of $30$.  $\greenD{\dfrac{8}{5}}=\dfrac{\greenD{8} \times {6}}{\greenD{5} \times {6}} = {\dfrac\greenD{48}\greenD{30}}$  $\purpleD{\dfrac{1}{6}}=\dfrac{\purpleD{1} \times 5}{\purpleD{6} \times 5} = {\dfrac\purpleD{5}\purpleD{30}}$

images.alt: Two groups with two rectangles each. The rectangles in the top group are split into 5 equal parts each. Each part is further split into 6 smaller equal groups. Forty-eight of the smaller groups are shaded. A curved bracket across the shaded parts is labeled forty-eight thirtieths. The rectangles in the bottom group are split into 6 equal parts each. Each part is further split into 5 equal parts. Five parts are shaded in purple. Forty-three parts are shaded in pink. The shaded parts in the bottom group are equal in size to the shaded part in the top group. A curved bracket across the purple shaded parts is labeled five-thirtieths. A curved bracket below the pink shaded parts is labeled forty-eight thirtieths minus five-thirtieths.

images.alt: Two groups with one rectangle each. The rectangle in the top group is split into 5 equal parts. Each part is labeled one-fifth. Four parts are shaded. There is a line dividing the seventh part of the bottom rectangle into two unequal parts. This line aligns with the end of the shaded part of the top group of rectangles. A curved bracket across the shaded part is labeled two-eighths. A curved bracket below the unequal segment of the bottom rectangle is labeled four-fifths minus two-eighths.

hints.content: Let's look at the multiples of each denominator and see which multiples they have in common.  Denominator | Multiples :-: | :-: $\greenD{5}$ | $5,  {10}, 15, 20, 25, 30, 35, \underline{40}$ $\purpleD{8}$ | $8, 16, 24,  32, \underline{40}$  The least common denominator is ${40}$.

Let's use multiplication to make each fraction have a denominator of $40$.  $\greenD{\dfrac{4}{5}}=\dfrac{\greenD{4} \times {8}}{\greenD{5} \times {8}} = {\dfrac\greenD{32}\greenD{40}}$  $\purpleD{\dfrac{2}{8}}=\dfrac{\purpleD{2} \times 5}{\purpleD{8} \times 5} = {\dfrac\purpleD{10}\purpleD{40}}$

hints.content: Let's look at the multiples of each denominator and see which multiples they have in common.  Denominator | Multiples :-: | :-: $\greenD{5}$ | $5,  \underline{10}, 15$ $\purpleD{10}$ | $ \underline{10}, 20, 30$  The least common denominator is ${10}$.
Let's use multiplication to make each fraction have a denominator of $10$.  $\greenD{\dfrac{8}{5}}=\dfrac{\greenD{8} \times {2}}{\greenD{5} \times {2}} = {\dfrac\greenD{16}\greenD{10}}$

hints.content: $\greenD{\dfrac{8}{5}} - \purpleD{\dfrac{2}{10}} = \dfrac{14}{10}$  We can also write $\dfrac{14}{10}$ as $\dfrac{7}{5}$, or $1\dfrac25$.

Let's use multiplication to make each fraction have a denominator of $24$.  $\greenD{\dfrac{8}{6}}=\dfrac{\greenD{8} \times {4}}{\greenD{6} \times {4}} = {\dfrac\greenD{32}\greenD{24}}$  $\purpleD{\dfrac{1}{8}}=\dfrac{\purpleD{1} \times 3}{\purpleD{8} \times 3} = {\dfrac\purpleD{3}\purpleD{24}}$

hints.content: Let's look at the multiples of each denominator and see which multiples they have in common.  Denominator | Multiples :-: | :-: $\greenD{6}$ | $6, 12, 18, \underline{24}$ $\purpleD{8}$ | $ 8, 16, \underline{24}$  The least common denominator is ${24}$.

Let's use multiplication to make each fraction have a denominator of $24$.  $\greenD{\dfrac{5}{6}}=\dfrac{\greenD{5} \times {4}}{\greenD{6} \times {4}} = {\dfrac\greenD{20}\greenD{24}}$  $\purpleD{\dfrac{4}{8}}=\dfrac{\purpleD{4} \times 3}{\purpleD{8} \times 3} = {\dfrac\purpleD{12}\purpleD{24}}$

hints.content: Let's look at the multiples of each denominator and see which multiples they have in common.  Denominator | Multiples :-: | :-: $\greenD{8}$ | $8, 16, 24, 32, \underline{40}$ $\purpleD{10}$ | $10, 20, 30, \underline{40}$  The least common denominator is ${40}$.

hints.content: Let's look at the multiples of each denominator and see which multiples they have in common.  Denominator | Multiples :-: | :-: $\greenD{8}$ | $8, 16, \underline{24}$ $\purpleD{12}$ | $12, \underline{24}, 36$  The least common denominator is ${24}$.

Let's use multiplication to make each fraction have a denominator of $24$.  $\greenD{\dfrac{9}{8}}=\dfrac{\greenD{9} \times {3}}{\greenD{8} \times {3}} = {\dfrac\greenD{27}\greenD{24}}$  $\purpleD{\dfrac{5}{12}}=\dfrac{\purpleD{5} \times 2}{\purpleD{12} \times 2} = {\dfrac\purpleD{10}\purpleD{24}}$

hints.content: Let's look at the multiples of each denominator and see which multiples they have in common.  Denominator | Multiples :-: | :-: $\greenD{12}$ | $12, 24, 36, 48, \underline{60}$ $\purpleD{10}$ | $10, 20, 30, 40, 50, \underline{60}$  The least common denominator is ${60}$.

Let's use multiplication to make each fraction have a denominator of $60$.  $\greenD{\dfrac{6}{12}}=\dfrac{\greenD{6} \times {5}}{\greenD{12} \times {5}} = {\dfrac\greenD{30}\greenD{60}}$  $\purpleD{\dfrac{3}{10}}=\dfrac{\purpleD{3} \times 6}{\purpleD{10} \times 6} = {\dfrac\purpleD{18}\purpleD{60}}$
